key_facts: The Rio Negro has reached its lowest recorded water level.
A severe drought in the Amazon is worsened by climate change and reduced rainfall.
This is the worst drought in the region in over 120 years.
Dried riverbeds and stranded boats are widespread.
Freshwater dolphins are dying due to the drought.
Over 40 million residents rely on these rivers for food, water, and transport.
Local businesses, like those in Puraquequara, are reporting major losses.
The drought affects both the environment and regional economies.
The current drought is considered the most intense in Brazilâ€™s history.
Communities face critical shortages of essential resources.
